title: Fassuliotis v. Fassuliotis
text:
<!--
.style1 {font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif}
-->




  THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR. 
  THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Supreme Court
  
  
    
      
        
          Maureen G. Fassuliotis, Respondent,
        
      
    
  
  v.
  
    
      
        
          Dennis T. Fassuliotis, Appellant.
        
      
    
  
  
  Appeal From Charleston County
  Â FrancesÂ  P. Segars-Andrews, Family Court Judge
  
  Memorandum Opinion No. 2004-MO-058
  Heard October 19, 2004 â€“ Filed November 8, 2004
  
  REVERSED
  
  
    
      
        
          Cynthia Barrier Castengera, of Newland, N.C., for Appellant.
          Sabrina R. Grogan, of Mt. Pleasant, for Respondent.
        
      
    
  
  
  PER CURIAM:Â  Reversed pursuant to Rule 220(b), SCACR, and the following authority: Edwards v. Edwards, 254 S.C. 466, 176 S.E.2d 123 (1970) (Contempt results from the willful disobedience of an order of the court, and before a person may be held in contempt, the record must be clear and specific as to the acts or conduct upon which such finding is based).Â  In light of our holding, the imposition of costs is likewised reversed.
  REVERSED.
  TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

title: Self v. State
text:
<!--
.style1 {font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif}
-->




  THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR. 
  THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Supreme Court
  
    
      
        
          Travis Self, Petitioner,
        
      
    
  
  v.
  
    
      
        
          State of South Carolina, Respondent.
        
      
    
  
  
  ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI
  
  Appeal From Florence County
  James E. Lockemy, Trial Judge
  Â B. Hicks Harwell, Jr., Post-Conviction Relief Judge
  
  Memorandum Opinion 2004-MO-059
  Submitted October 20, 2004 â€“ Filed November 8, 2004
  
  AFFIRMED
  
  
    
      
        
          John Wesley Locklair, III, of Joye & Locklair, P.A. of Murrells Inlet, for Petitioner.
          Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, all of the Office of the Attorney General, of Columbia, for Respondent.
        
      
    
  
  
  PER CURIAM:Â  Petitioner seeks a writ of certiorari from the denial of his application for post-conviction relief (PCR).Â  The petition is denied on petitionerâ€™s Questions I and II.
  Because there is sufficient evidence to support the PCR judgeâ€™s finding that petitioner did not knowingly and intelligently waive his right to a direct appeal, we grant certiorari on petitionerâ€™s Question III and proceed with a review of the direct appeal issue pursuant to Davis v. State, 288 S.C. 290, 342 S.E.2d 60 (1986).
  Petitionerâ€™s convictions and sentences are affirmed pursuant to Rule 220(b)(1), SCACR, and the following authority: State v. Hornsby, 326 S.C. 121, 484 S.E.2d 869 (1997) (a jury charge is not preserved for appellate review unless a party either requested the charge and obtained a ruling, or objected on specific grounds to the charge as given); State v. Sprouse, 325 S.C. 275, 478 S.E.2d 871 (Ct. App. 1996).
  AFFIRMED.
  TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

title: Burks v. State
text:
<!--
.style1 {font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif}
-->




  THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
  THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Supreme Court
  
    
      
        
          Troy Burks, Petitioner,
          v.
          State of South Carolina, Respondent.
        
      
    
  
  
  ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI
  
  Appeal From Greenville County
  C. Victor Pyle, Jr., Trial Judge
  Â John C. Few, Post-Conviction Relief Judge
  
  Memorandum Opinion No. 2004-MO-061
  Submitted October 19, 2004 â€“ Filed November 8, 2004
  
  REVERSED
  
  
    
      
        
          Assistant Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, S.C. Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
          Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Christopher L. Newton, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
        
      
    
  
  
  PER CURIAM:Â  The circuit court granted petitioner a belated review of the denial of his first application for post-conviction relief (PCR) pursuant to Austin v. State, 305 S.C. 453, 409 S.E.2d 395 (1991).Â  Counsel for petitioner has failed to follow the procedure set forth in King v. State, 308 S.C. 348, 417 S.E.2d 868 (1992).Â  No petition for a writ of certiorari alleging that the PCR judge properly granted petitioner an Austin review was filed.Â  Instead, counsel filed only an Austin petition, pursuant to Johnson v. State, 294 S.C. 310, 364 S.E.2d 201 (1988), and a request to be relieved as counsel.Â  Petitioner has filed a pro se response to the Johnson petition and a request for production of documents.
  We issue a writ of certiorari to address the question of whether the PCR judge properly granted petitioner an Austin review, dispense with further briefing, and reverse the order of the PCR judge.Â  In addition, we deny petitionerâ€™s request for production of documents as the material petitioner asks for is not necessary for a decision in this matter.
  Â Following the denial of petitionerâ€™s first PCR application, a petition for a writ of certiorari was filed with this Court.Â  After reviewing the merits, we denied the petition.Â  Accordingly, we reverse the order of the PCR judge since his finding that petitioner was entitled to an Austin review of the denial of his first PCR application is not supported by the record.Â  Rogers v. State, 317 S.C. 392, 453 S.E.2d 892 (1995) (PCR judgeâ€™s findings will not be upheld if there is no probative evidence to support them).
  Because petitioner is not entitled to an Austin review, we decline to address the Austin petition filed by counsel or the pro se response thereto filed by petitioner.
  REVERSED.



  TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.

v.

ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Spartanburg County
Henry F. Floyd, Trial Judge
Â J. Derham Cole, Post-Conviction Relief Judge

Memorandum Opinion No. 2004-MO-062
Submitted October 25, 2004 â€“ Filed November 8, 2004

DISMISSED


  
    
      
        Assistant Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, of the Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
        Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General Douglas Leadbitter, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  Petitioner seeks a writ of certiorari from the denial of his application for post-conviction relief (PCR).
Because there is sufficient evidence to support the PCR judgeâ€™s finding that petitioner did not knowingly and intelligently waive his right to a direct appeal, we grant certiorari and proceed with a review of the direct appeal issue pursuant to Davis v. State, 288 S.C. 290, 342 S.E.2d 60 (1986).
The direct appeal issues are dismissed under Rule 220(b)(1), SCACR, after a review pursuant to Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967).Â  Counselâ€™s motion to be relieved is granted.
DISMISSED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL 
  VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT 
  AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR. 
THE STATE 
  OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Supreme Court

 
   
     
       
        Sammy Brownlee, 
          Petitioner,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
       
        State of South 
          Carolina, Respondent.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI 
  

Appeal From Abbeville 
  County
  Â Larry R. Patterson, Plea Judge
  James W. Johnson, Post-Conviction Judge

Memorandum Opinion No. 
  2004-MO-063
  Submitted October 26, 2004 â€“ Filed November 8, 2004

APPEAL DISMISSED

 
   
     
       
        Assistant Appellate Defender 
          Tara S. Taggart, of the South Carolina Office of Appellate Defense, 
          of Columbia, for Petitioner.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan 
          McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant 
          Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General 
          Molly R. Crum, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  Petitioner seeks 
  a writ of certiorari from an order of the circuit court denying his application 
  for post-conviction relief (PCR) and granting him a belated direct appeal pursuant 
  to White v. State, 263 S.C. 110, 208 S.E.2d 35 (1974).Â  
We deny the petition as to Question 
  2, but grant the petition for a writ of certiorari as to Question 1 and proceed 
  with a review of the direct appeal issue pursuant to Davis v. State, 
  288 S.C. 290, 342 S.E.2d 60 (1986).
Petitionerâ€™s counsel has submitted 
  a brief pursuant to Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738, 87 S.Ct. 1396, 
  18 L.Ed.2d 49(1967) and a petition to be relieved as counsel.Â  Petitioner has 
  filed a pro se brief.
After careful consideration of the 
  entire record as required by Anders and State v. Williams, 305 
  S.C. 116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), the direct appeal is dismissed pursuant to 
  Rule 220(b)(1), SCACR.Â  The petition to be relieved as counsel is granted.
DISMISSED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT 
  and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR. 
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

  
    
      
        James R. Wilson, Petitioner,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        State of South Carolina, Respondent.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Abbeville County
James W. Johnson, Jr., Trial Judge
Â Wyatt T. Saunders, Jr., Post-Conviction Relief Judge

Memorandum Opinion No. 2004-MO-064
Submitted October 26, 2004 â€“ Filed November 8, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Senior Assistant Appellate Defender Wanda H. Haile, of the Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
        Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General Adrianne L. Turner, all of the Office of the Attorney General, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  Petitioner seeks a writ of certiorari from an order of the circuit court denying his application for post-conviction relief (PCR) and finding petitioner is entitled to a belated appeal pursuant to White v. State, 263 S.C. 110, 208 S.E.2d 35 (1974).Â  
We grant the petition for a writ of certiorari and proceed with a review of the direct appeal issue pursuant to Davis v. State, 288 S.C. 290, 342 S.E.2d 60 (1986).Â  We affirm pursuant to Rule 220(b)(1), SCACR, and the following authorities:Â  Rule 401, SCRE; Rule 403, SCRE; State v. Gay, 343 S.C. 543, 541 S.E.2d 541 (2001); State v. Johnson, 338 S.C. 114, 525 S.E.2d 519 (2000); State v. Powers, 331 S.C. 37, 501 S.E.2d 116 (1998).
AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

title: Jones v. State
text:
<!--
.style1 {font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif}
-->



  THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR. 
  THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
      
In The Supreme Court
  
    
      
        
          Jimmy Dean Jones, Petitioner,
        
      
    
  
  v.
  
    
      
        
          State of South Carolina, Respondent.
        
      
    
  
  
  ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI
  
  Appeal From Spartanburg County
  Â Donald W. Beatty, Plea Judge
  J. Derham Cole, Post-Conviction Relief Judge
  
  Memorandum Opinion No. 2004-MO-060
  Submitted October 20, 2004 â€“ Filed November 11, 2004
  
  VACATED
  
  
    
      
        
          Assistant Appellate Defender Aileen P. Claire, of the South Carolina Office of Appellate Defense, for Petitioner.
          Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, and Assistant Attorney General Douglas E. Leadbitter, of the Office of the Attorney General, for Respondent.
        
      
    
  
  
  PER CURIAM:Â  Petitioner seeks a writ of certiorari from the denial of his application for post-conviction relief (PCR).Â  We grant the petition, dispense with further briefing, and vacate petitionerâ€™s guilty plea to accessory after the fact to burglary second (accessory after the fact).
  Petitioner pled guilty to accessory after the fact and was sentenced to a term of imprisonment of five years provided that upon service of two years the balance was suspended with probation for three years.Â  No direct appeal was taken.Â  Petitionerâ€™s PCR application was dismissed following an evidentiary hearing.Â  He now, for the first time on appeal, contends the circuit court did not have subject matter jurisdiction to accept his guilty plea because he was indicted for second degree burglary and accessory after the fact is not a lesser included offense of second degree burglary.Â  We agree.Â  
  Lack of subject matter jurisdiction can be raised at any time, including for the first time on appeal to this Court.Â  State v. Funderburk, 259 S.C. 256, 191 S.E.2d 520 (1972).Â  A circuit court has subject matter jurisdiction if there has been an indictment that sufficiently states the offense, there has been a waiver of indictment, or the charge is a lesser included offense of the crime charged in the indictment.Â  Locke v. State, 341 S.C. 54, 533 S.E.2d 324 (2000).Â  The test for determining if a crime is a lesser included offense is whether the greater of the two offenses includes all the elements of the lesser offense.Â  Knox v. State, 340 S.C. 81, 530 S.E.2d 887 (2000).Â  


  Petitionerâ€™s indictment for second degree burglary stated petitioner did â€œin Spartanburg County on or about July 14, 1998 willfully and unlawfully enter without consent and with the intent to commit a crime therein, a building to wit: The building of Z.L. Madden Elementary School, 459 West Centennial, Spartanburg, South Carolina, and the defendant did enter in the nighttime.â€Â  The elements of accessory after the fact are: (1) the underlying felony has been completed; (2) the accused had knowledge that the principal committed the felony; and (3) the accused harbored or assisted the felon.Â  State v. Hodges, 278 S.C. 110, 292 S.E.2d 600 (1982).
  The indictment for second degree burglary does not include any of the necessary elements of accessory after the fact.Â  Accordingly, accessory after the fact is not a lesser included offense of second degree burglary, and in the absence of a waiver of indictment for that charge the circuit court did not have subject matter jurisdiction to accept petitionerâ€™s guilty plea to accessory after the fact.Â  We vacate petitionerâ€™s guilty plea to accessory after the fact. 
  VACATED.
  TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

title: Wright v. State
text:
<!--
.style1 {font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif}
-->



THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Marquiz C. Wright, Petitioner,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        State of South Carolina, Respondent.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI 

Appeal From Greenville County
Rodney A. Peeples, Circuit Court Judge
Â John W. Kittredge, Post-Conviction Judge

Memorandum Opinion No. 2004-MO-067
Submitted November 1, 2004 â€“ Filed November 29, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Richard Harold Warder, of Greenville, for Petitioner.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General Elizabeth R. McMahon, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  Petitioner seeks a writ of certiorari from an order denying his application for post-conviction relief (PCR) and granting him a belated review of his direct appeal issue pursuant to White v. State, 263 S.C. 110, 208 S.E.2d 35 (1974).Â  
Question I of the petition for a writ of certiorari is denied.Â  Petitioner has failed to address in his petition whether the PCR judge correctly found petitioner was entitled to a belated review of his direct appeal issue as required by Davis v. State, 288 S.C. 290, 342 S.E.2d 60 (1986), and Rule 227(h), SCACR.Â  Therefore, the direct appeal issue is not properly before this Court.Â  However, because the record establishes petitioner did not knowingly and voluntarily waive his right to a direct appeal, we grant certiorari to review the direct appeal issue presented as Question II in the petition.Â Â  
We affirm petitionerâ€™s conviction and sentence pursuant to Rule 220(b)(1), SCACR, and the following authority: State v. Aldret, 333 S.C. 307, 509 S.E.2d 811 (1999) (finding contemporaneous objection must be made to preserve an issue for appellate review).
AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

title: State v. Williams
text:
<!--
.style1 {font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif}
-->



THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        John Williams, III, Petitioner.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE 
COURT OF APPEALS

Appeal From Greenville County
Â H. Dean Hall, Circuit Court Judge

Memorandum Opinion No. 2004-MO-068
Heard December 7, 2003 â€“ Filed November 29, 2004

AFFIRMED

Chief Attorney Daniel T. Stacey, of S.C. Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia, and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.

JUSTICE WALLER:Â  We granted a writ of certiorari to review the Court of Appealsâ€™ opinion in State v. Williams, Op. No. 2001-UP-324 (Ct. App. filed June 18, 2001).Â  The sole issue on certiorari is whether Williams was entitled to a circumstantial evidence charge pursuant to State v. Edwards, 298 S.C. 272, 379 S.E.2d 888, cert. denied, 493 U.S. 895 (1989).Â  This matter is affirmed in light of our opinion in State v. Cherry, Op. No. 25902, S.C. Sup. Ct. filed November 29, 2004, (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 46).
AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT, JJ., and Acting Justice Reginald I. Lloyd, concur.
